sn35.80:1.1: Then a monk went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.80:1.2: “Sir, is there one system such that by giving it up a monk gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
sn35.80:4.1: “Ignorance is one system such that by giving it up a monk gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
sn35.80:5.1: “But how does a monk know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
sn35.80:6.2: ‘The system of the universe is not worth holding on to.’
sn35.80:6.3: When a monk has heard that
sn35.80:6.4: the system of the universe is not worth holding on to,
sn35.80:6.5: they directly know the system of the universe. Directly knowing the system of the universe, they completely understand the system of the universe. Completely understanding the system of the universe, they see the signs of the universe as other. They see the seer, the seen,
sn35.80:6.8: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as other. …
sn35.80:6.12: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as other.
sn35.80:6.13: That’s how a monk knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
